answers.answer: Most doctors recommend sticking with the first due date your given . A due date can change if there's to much amniotic fluid or how baby is positioned . They also give or take two weeks . But first ultrasound and due dates are pretty much accurate . If you keep measuring ahead your ob may want to check you well he will any way to see if gestational diabetes is a factor playing in .
Will getting your cervix checked determine it also?

Were you given the original due date before having the ultrasound? If so, go with the second date. I was originally given a dd of july 19 going by my last menstrual cycle but it changed to august 10 after the ultrasound. Ultrasounds are usually pretty good early on in pregnancy, they can usually tell to the exact date how old the embryo/fetus is.
Yeah but I have way more symptoms that go along with my first due date an my baby is around the size of my first due date but he will come when he comes (:

Some symptoms come and go so you can't really judge a due date by those, they can change and show up randomly or not show up at all. Has you doctor mentioned that baby is measuring behind? Or are you judging based on the app or google. Babies grow at different rates and you still have plenty of time for a growth spurt! :)
No baby is measuring bigger than he should be if it was my new due date
Oh whoops, I misunderstood that part!

question: Okay so have any of you heard of an ultrasound being wrong for due day because I was told at first that I was due July 16 then told August 5th after ultrasound an I am having way more symptoms that are supposed to be going on with my first due date an baby is more the size of the first due date??? Help
title: Mommys
